50.text:
Except for a few exceptions, life expectancy

55.text:
was a privilege, not a right. In all those
millennia, we never developed a weapon that

59.text:
could kill more than a couple dozen people

You have electricity? Industrial Revolution.

The Industrial Revolution was an increase
in production brought about by the use of

158.text:
The innovations of the Industrial Revolution
were intimately interconnected. Like, look,

161.text:
for instance, at the British textile industry:
The invention of the flying shuttle by John

166.text:
Kay in 1733 dramatically increased the speed
of weaving, which in turn created demand for

171.text:
yarn, which led to inventions like the Spinning
Jenny and the water frame. Soon these processes

176.text:
were mechanized using water power, until the
steam engine came along to make flying shuttles

180.text: really fly in these huge cotton mills.

183.text:
The most successful steam engine was built
by Thomas “They Didn’t Name Anything After

187.text:
Me” Newcomen to clear water out of mines.
And because water was cleared out of those

192.text:
mines, there was more coal to power more steam
engines, which eventually led to the fancying

196.text:
up of the Newcomen Steam Engine by James “I
Got a Unit of Power and a University Named

200.text:
After Me” Watt, whose engine made possible
not only railroads and steamboats but also

used to bleach the cloth that people wore

247.text:
So, the problem here is that with industrialization
being so deeply interconnected, it’s really

252.text:
difficult to figure out why it happened in
Europe, especially Britain. And that question

256.text:
of why turns out to be one of the more contentious
discussions in world history today.

259.text:
For instance, here are some Eurocentric reasons
why industrialization might have happened

263.text:
first in Europe: There’s the cultural superiority
argument that basically holds that Europeans

267.text:
are just better and smarter than other people.
Sometimes this is formulated as Europeans

272.text:
possessing superior rationality. By the way,
you’ll never guess where the people who

275.text:
make this argument tend to come from - unless
you guessed that they come from Europe.

279.text:
And then, others argue that only Europe had
the culture of science and invention that

282.text:
made the creation of these revolutionary technologies
possible. Another argument is that freer political

287.text:
institutions encouraged innovation and strong
property rights created incentives for inventors.

292.text:
And, finally, people often cite Europe’s
small population because small populations

295.text:
require labor-saving inventions. Oh, it’s
time for the Open Letter?

303.text:
An Open Letter to the Steam Engine. But first,
let’s see what’s in the secret compartment

307.text:
today. Oh, it’s a TARDIS. Truly the apex

312.text:
Dear Steam Engine, You know what’s crazy?
You’ve really never been improved upon.

317.text:
Like this thing, which facilitates time travel,
probably runs on a steam engine. Almost all

electricity around the world, whether it’s

It’s all still just water and heat, and

Revolution was that since then, it’s really

335.text:
So, you may have heard any of those rationales
for European industrialization, or you may

339.text:
have heard others. The problem with all of
them, is that each time you think you’re

342.text:
at the root cause it turns out there’s a
cause of the root cause. To quote Leonardo

347.text:
DiCaprio, James Cameron, and coal mine operators,
“We have to go deeper.”

350.text:
But, anyway, the problem with these Eurocentric
why answers, is that they all apply to either

354.text:
China or India or both. And it’s really
important to note that in 1800, it was not

359.text:
clear that Europe was going to become the
world’s dominant manufacturing power in

362.text:
the next hundred years. At the time, China,
India, and Europe were all roughly at the

366.text: same place in terms of industrial production.

368.text:
First, let’s look at China. It’s hard
to make the European cultural superiority

371.text:
argument because China had been recording
its history since before Confucius, and plus

375.text:
there was all that bronze and painting and
poetry.

378.text:
It’s also kind of difficult to make a blanket
statement that China was economically inferior

382.text:
to Europe, since they invented paper money
and led the world in exports of everything

386.text:
from silk to china. I mean, pre-Industrial
Revolution, population growth was the surest

390.text:
sign of economic success, and China had the
biggest population in the world. I guess that

395.text:
answers the question of whether they’re
digital.

396.text:
It’s also difficult to say that China lacked
a culture of invention when they invented

400.text:
gunpowder, and printing, and paper, and arguably
compasses. And China had more free enterprise

405.text:
during the Song dynasty than anywhere in the
world.

407.text:
Some argue that China couldn’t have free
enterprise because they had a long history

410.text:
of trying to impose monopolies on items like
salt and iron. And that’s true, but when

414.text:
it comes to enforcing those monopolies, they
also had a long history of failure. So really,

418.text:
in a lot of ways, China was at least as primed
for an Industrial Revolution as Britain was.

422.text:
So, why didn’t it happen? Well, Europeans
- specifically the British - had two huge

427.text:
advantages: First, Coal. When you trace the
story of improved transportation, or communication,

431.text:
or industrial efficiency, or better chemical
manufacturing, it always comes back to coal,

437.text:
because the Industrial Revolution was all about
using different forms of energy to automate production.

442.text:
And England had large supplies of coal that
were near the surface, which meant that it

445.text:
was cheap to mine, so it quickly replaced
wood for heating and cooking and stuff. So

450.text:
that encouraged the British to look for more
coal. The only problem with coal mining, aside

453.text:
from it being, you know, like, deadly and
everything, is that the coal mines flooded

456.text:
all the time. I guess coal mining is also
a little problematic for, like, the health

459.text: of, you know, like, the planet.

460.text:
But, because there was all this incentive
to get more coal out of the ground, steam

464.text:
engines were invented to pump water out of
the mines. And because those early steam engines

467.text:
were super inefficient, they needed a cheap
and abundant source of fuel in order to work

472.text:
- namely, coal, which meant they were much
more useful to the British than anyone else.

476.text:
So steam engines used cheap British coal to
keep British coal cheap, and cheap British

480.text:
coal created the opportunity for everything
from railroads to steel, which like so much

484.text:
else in the Industrial Revolution, created
a positive feedback loop. Because they run

488.text:
on rails, railroads need steel. And because
it is rather heavy, steel needs railroads.

493.text:
Secondly, there were Wages. Britain (and to
a lesser extent the Low Countries) had the

497.text:
highest wages in the world at the beginning
of the 18th century. In 1725, wages in London

502.text:
were the equivalent of 11 grams of silver
per day. In Amsterdam, they were 9 grams.

506.text:
In Beijing, Venice, and Florence, they were
under 4. And in Delhi, they were under 2.

510.text:
It’s not totally clear why wages were so
high in Britain. Like, one argument is that

513.text:
the Black Death lowered population so much
that it tightened labor markets, but that

517.text:
doesn’t explain why wages remained low in,
like, plague-ravaged Italy. Mainly, high wages

521.text:
combined with cheap fuel costs meant that
it was economically efficient for manufacturers

525.text:
to look to machines as a way of lowering their
production costs. To quote the historian Robert

529.text:
Allen: “Wages were high and energy was cheap.
These prices led directly to the industrial

534.text:
revolution by giving firms strong incentives
to invent technologies that substituted capital

541.text:
Ugh, Stan, I’m a little worried that people
are still going to accuse me of Eurocentrism.

544.text:
Of course, other people will accuse me of
an anti-European bias. I don’t have a bias

548.text:
against Europe. I love Europe. Europe gave
me many of my favorite cheeses and cross-country

553.text:
skiing and Charlie Chaplin, who inspired today’s
Danica drawing.

557.text:
Like, the fact of coal being near the surface
in Britain can’t be chalked up to British

560.text:
cultural superiority. But the wages question
is a little different because it makes it

564.text:
sound like only Europeans were smart enough
to pay high wages.

567.text:
But here’s one last thing to consider: India
was the world’s largest producer of cotton

571.text:
textiles, despite paying basically the lowest
wages in the world. Indian agriculture was

575.text:
so productive that laborers could be supported
at a very low cost. And that, coupled with

579.text:
a large population, meant that Indian textile
manufacturing could be very productive without

583.text: using machines, so they didn’t need to industrialize.

585.text:
But more importantly from our perspective,
there’s a strong argument to be made that

588.text:
Indian cotton production helped spur British
industrialization. It was cotton textiles

592.text:
that drove the early Industrial Revolution,
and the main reason that Britain was so eager

596.text:
to produce cottons was that demand was incredibly
high. They were more comfortable than woolens,

601.text:
but they were also cheaper, because cottons
could be imported from India at such a low cost.

605.text:
So, Indian cottons created the market and
then British manufacturers invested in machines

610.text:
(and imported Indian know-how) to increase
production so that they could compete with

614.text:
India. And that’s at least one way in which
European industrialization was truly a world

618.text:
phenomenon. For those of you who enjoy such
highly contentious and thorny, cultural historical

623.text:
debates, good news. Next week, we’ll be
talking about capitalism.
